Lack of sleep can cause hallucinations by essentially causing a person to enter a dreaming-type state while still awake. This happens to me at around 50 hours of being awake.I've noticed that with less than 7-9 hours of sleep, I will slip into that sleep/dream state since taking the Baclofen. Hallucinations can be an extremely disturbing side effect, but they are less frightening if you know that it is likely a dream-type situation rather than a serious mental health problem. If you do experience these side effects, try getting more sleep before calling a psychiatrist.But so far it has been a great pain reliever for me, and should be investigated further for IBS patients, especially those who aren't helped enough by Donnatal or Amitriptylene or other -triptylene drugs. column9: My mother was placed on 20mg 2x day in addition to her other pain management meds, which she had been on for several years and tolerated very well. She was not started on a lower dose and titrated up, as recommended.I myself, was not informed that this med was started...my mother was told "it is a muscle relaxer that might help". She has severe degenerative changes in her spinal area, as well as neuropathy in her legs.She was on Baclofen at 20 mg 2x day for less than 2 weeks. She had extreme auditory/ visual hallucinations and confusion;I thought she had experienced a stroke or cerebral bleed from what she was exhibiting, and from the onset of symptoms. This resulted in a fall where she had fractured both legs and had multiple contusions. She has been hospitalized, was in ICU for 1 week,and is currently STILL in rehab unable to stand or bear weight.She looks to be at least 3 weeks away from d/c and then ongoing home PT to regain mobility.PLEASE use caution in starting ANY new drug, especially in the elderly. This was prescribed by a pain management MD, and I feel that too little caution was taken in judging my mother's tolerance/ ability to use this med in addition to the other med's she was on. Also, too little education re : side effects to look out for...now her and our ability to care for her is very uncertain because of a lack of caution on the guesswork of one patient's tolerance/ reaction to a "starting" dose over another's....I've read the other reviews where hallucinations/ confusion have been experienced, and would be interested in knowing what dosages they were on/ started on, or any other instances of similar reactions.
